facts.text: Petitioner is a resident of Ujjain and a citizen of India. He had been a voter in all previous general elections and claims to be a voter in Daulatganj, Ward No. 5, in the Electoral Roll of Ujjain.
Petitioner claims to have a right to contest the election to any Assembly or Parliamentary constituency in the State of Madhya Pradesh.
Impugned notification published in the Gazette of India Extraordinary on July 24, 1964, shows Ujjain as a Constituency reserved for the scheduled castes.
Notification made in pursuance of sub-s. (1) to s. 10 of the Delimitation Commission Act, 1962.

Proposals of the Delimitation Commission for delimitation of Parliamentary and Assembly constituencies in Madhya Pradesh published on October 15, 1963 in the Gazette of India and official gazette of the State.
After considering all objections and suggestions, the Commission determined the territorial constituencies.
Petition under Art. 226 filed in Madhya Pradesh High Court, Misc. Petition No. 72 of 1965, praying for writ of certiorari to quash the notification.
High Court summarily dismissed the petition on February 25, 1965, on the ground that under Art. 329(a) the notification could not be questioned in any court.
Petition alleges many acts of omission and commission on the part of the Commission and its Chairman.
Ujjain city has been from the inception of the Constitution a general constituency.
By converting Ujjain into a reserved constituency, petitioner's right to be a candidate for Parliament from this constituency has been taken away.
Delimitation Commission constituted under Section 3 of Delimitation Commission Act, 1962.
Duty of Commission under Sections 4, 8, 9 of the Act to readjust allocation of seats and delimit constituencies based on latest census figures.
Orders under Sections 8 and 9 published under Section 10(1) in Gazette of India and State gazettes, having force of law under Section 10(2), not to be called in question in any court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the impugned notification is a law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats to such constituencies, made or purporting to be made under Article 327, so as to be protected from challenge in any court under Article 329(a).
Whether the Delimitation Commission Act, 1962 was passed by Parliament under Article 327 or under Article 82.
Whether an order under Sections 8 or 9 of the Delimitation Commission Act, published under Section 10(1), has the force of law equivalent to a law made under Article 327.

petitioner_arguments.text: The notification referred to is not law and was not made under Art. 327 of the Constitution.
Delimitation Commission Act, 1962, was passed under Art. 82, not Art. 327.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Preamble to Delimitation Commission Act, 1962; Article 82

petitioner_arguments.text: Order under s.9 has force of law but is not itself a law.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: His Majesty the King v. William Singer (Canada); Sangram Singh v. Election Tribunal

petitioner_arguments.text: Ujjain city converted from general to reserved constituency, taking away right to contest.

respondent_arguments.text: Notification is law relating to delimitation made under Art. 327, barred by Art. 329(a).
Delimitation Commission Act made under Art. 327, orders under ss.8,9 have force of law.

court_reasoning.text: Article 82 envisages readjustment after census, but Art. 327 empowers Parliament to make provision for delimitation etc. Delimitation Commission Act made under Art. 327.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Preamble shows Act provides for readjustment under Art. 327 powers.

court_reasoning.text: Orders under ss.8,9 published under s.10(1) have force of law under s.10(2), cannot be questioned in court, supersede prior laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Intention of legislature to treat orders as binding law, not mere administrative directions.

court_reasoning.text: Notification is law relating to delimitation purporting to be made under Art. 327, protected by Art. 329(a).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Though not statute, has effect of law made by Parliament.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Canadian case: Here s.10(2) makes orders have force of law and not callable in question, unlike mere force without being Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Orders treated as law for purpose of Art. 329(a).

court_reasoning.text: High Court correctly relied on N.P. Punnuswami; Art. 329(a) bars challenge to delimitation laws.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Scheme of Part XV excludes court interference in delimitation.

court_reasoning.text: Allows finality to prevent voters holding up elections by challenging delimitation.

holdings.text: Orders under ss.8 and 9 of Delimitation Commission Act, 1962, published under s.10(1), have the force of law and shall not be called in question in any court under Art. 329(a).
Delimitation Commission Act, 1962 enacted under Art. 327.
Impugned notification cannot be challenged in court.

precedents_cited.case_name: His Majesty the King v. William Singer
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished as orders there had force of law but not deemed Act of Parliament; here explicitly not to be questioned.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sangram Singh v. Election Tribunal, Kotah
precedents_cited.relevance: Tribunal orders final but subject to constitutional jurisdiction unless barred by Constitution like Art. 329(a).

precedents_cited.case_name: N.P. Punnuswami v. Returning Officer, Namakkal Constituency
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 329(b) excludes High Court jurisdiction; extends to 329(a) for delimitation.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harishankar Bagla v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Orders under Essential Supplies Act have effect notwithstanding inconsistencies, like s.10(2) here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kailash Nath v. State of U.P.
precedents_cited.relevance: Notification under Sales Tax Act has statutory force as if in parent Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Jayantilal Amrit Lal Shodhan v. F.N. Rana
precedents_cited.relevance: Presidential notification under Art. 258(1) has force of law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Edward Mills Co. Ltd. v. State of Ajmer
precedents_cited.relevance: Order under repealed Act is law in force.
Art. 226 jurisdiction cannot be limited except by Constitution.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art. 327 empowers delimitation laws; Art. 329(a) bars challenge to such laws; others guide Commission's duties.

statutes_cited.name: Delimitation Commission Act, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Constitutes Commission, duties for readjustment and delimitation; orders have force of law, not question-able.

statutes_cited.name: Delimitation of Parliamentary and Assembly Constituencies Order, 1961

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upholding the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition. The impugned notification under the Delimitation Commission Act, 1962, was held to be a law relating to delimitation made under Article 327, not challengeable under Article 329(a).

key_quotes.text: "Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution the validity of any law relating to the delimitation of constituencies or the allotment of seats to such constituencies, made or purporting to be made under article 327 or article 328, shall not be called in question in any court."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Art. 329(a), central to barring challenge.

key_quotes.text: Upon publication in the Gazette of India, every such order shall have the force of law and shall not be called in question in any court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key provision s.10(2) making orders non-justiciable.

key_quotes.text: It cannot be otherwise. They are made to be obeyed and, as a consequence, they must have the force of law. But that is quite a different thing from saying that they will be deemed to be an Act of Parliament.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishing Canadian precedent on force of law vs. being law.

key_quotes.text: In effect, this means the complete effacement of all provisions of this nature which were in force before the passing of the orders under ss. 8 and 9 and only such orders were to hold the field.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains supersession effect of new delimitation.
